title: Building a CLI Application with Go
summary: Learn how to build a simple command-line interface (CLI) application using Go, harnessing the power of its standard library and popular packages.

body.raw: ## Introduction Command-Line Interface (CLI) applications provide users with a text-based interface to interact with software. With Go's robust standard library and efficient compilation, it's an excellent choice for building CLI tools. ## Setting Up Before you begin, ensure you have Go installed. If not, refer to the official [Go Installation Guide](https://golang.org/doc/install). ## Your First CLI Application We'll start by building a simple "Hello, World!" CLI application. ```go package main import ( "fmt" "os" ) func main() { if len(os.Args) < 2 { fmt.Println("Hello, World!") } else { fmt.Printf("Hello, %s!\n", os.Args[1]) } } ``` Save this code to a file named hello.go. To run the application, use: ```bash $ go run hello.go Hello, World! $ go run hello.go Alice Hello, Alice! ``` ### Parsing Command-Line Arguments While os.Args provides raw command-line arguments, Go offers the flag package for more complex command-line parsing. ```go package main import ( "flag" "fmt" ) func main() { name := flag.String("name", "World", "Name of the person to greet") flag.Parse() fmt.Printf("Hello, %s!\n", *name) } ``` You can now use flags to specify the name: ```bash $ go run hello.go --name=Alice Hello, Alice! ``` ## Organizing Commands with Cobra For more sophisticated CLI applications, the Cobra library is a popular choice. It allows for easy command organization, argument parsing, and provides helpful features like auto-generated help and shell completions. To get started with Cobra, you'd need to install it and set up a new Cobra CLI application. Follow their official documentation for a comprehensive guide.
